Hi,

On 10/01/2008, Ken Lloyd <kalloyd@...> wrote:
> It was interesting to me how these intelligent, learned men  framed the question - more
> correctly they missed the salient intent of the  question - therefore misframed the
> question when constructing their  answers.  This was as fascinating as it was often.
>
> A phenomenon akin to tunnel-vision sometimes sets in in the  minds of "experts" where
> the context of their expertise rejects or  transforms the query into something
> more palatable to their context.   I see this often in my work.


I guess we all suffer from a tunnel-vision effect to some degree.
While I was working on the Netflix prize last year I did a lot of
reading on the subject and it's really interesting to see how it has
changed the way I think about both new and old problems I encounter.
In the grand scheme of things Collaborative Filtering is a pretty
niche subject, and yet underlying it is a bunch of maths/statistics
that gives better understanding of certain real world problems.  Now
I'd like to think that as I learn new stuff that my understanding of
everything expands, but at the same time I suspect it might just be
moving a single narrow perspective around a bit :)

That said I wonder if some of these guys have ever thought about
evolution outside the context of biology. Biology is a fascinating
subject but biology does not equal evolution. It's a fundamental
phenomenon that gave rise to biology and lots of other things and I
wonder if someone like Wolpert has ever really thought about that.
You see, if you're really that interested in evolution AND you have
some exposure to computers, well then you're going to at least have a
tinker with EC aren't you? E.g. maybe just d/load an alife program
with a pretty GUI and just see what happens?



>  The fact that this tendency is reduced by  starting de novo or minimally is one of the
> particular strengths in  neuro-evolution.
>
> Learning to use these tools teaches us something not  only about the tools,
> but ourselves.

Nicely back on topic :)   Something I've mentioned a few times before
is how interesting it is to write a fitness function for a NEAT
experiment. They hardly ever work as you expect the first time because
NEAT finds solutions you wouldn't expect -  NEAT is very good at
findings holes in a fitness schemes and 'cheating'. It really forces
you to think about the problem you are /really/ trying to solve.

Colin
